# Do Other Countries Have Military Bases in the US?
 Do foreign nations have military bases in the US? Explore the nuanced reality of international military presence and US sovereign control.
       [LegalClarity Team](/users/8548/profile/legalclarity-team)    Published Aug 29, 2025      While the U.S. maintains a vast global military presence, foreign nations do not operate independent military bases within the United States. This article clarifies the distinctions between sovereign military bases and other forms of foreign military presence, and outlines the legal frameworks governing such activities on U.S. soil.

## The Absence of Foreign Military Bases in the United States
 Foreign nations do not operate independent, sovereign military bases on U.S. territory in the same manner that the United States maintains bases abroad. This policy is rooted in the principle of national sovereignty, which dictates that a nation has supreme authority within its own borders. The U.S. has historically maintained a stance against allowing foreign countries to establish their own military bases on its soil.
 While the U.S. has a vast network of military installations worldwide, often established through Status of Forces Agreements (SOFAs), no reciprocal agreements exist for foreign nations to establish independent bases in the U.S. The absence of foreign military bases reflects a long-standing U.S. policy that prioritizes its territorial integrity and military independence.
  Discover moreBase Location ServicesInternational relations coursesUS Defense StrategyGlobal security analysisUS foreign policy analysisSOFA legal guidesInternational law resourcesDefense contractor servicesCountry Relations ReportLegal Frameworks Guide 
## Distinguishing Foreign Military Presence from Bases
 A “military base” differs from other forms of “military presence.” A military base is typically a facility directly owned and operated by a military or one of its branches, sheltering equipment and personnel, and facilitating training and operations under its own sovereign control. Such a base implies a degree of extraterritoriality, where the laws of the operating nation might apply within the base’s confines.
 In contrast, foreign military presence in the U.S. refers to various activities and personnel that operate under the ultimate jurisdiction of U.S. law and are subject to specific agreements. These presences do not involve sovereign control over U.S. territory. Instead, they are collaborative arrangements that support mutual defense objectives, training, or logistical needs, always within the framework of U.S. regulations and oversight.

## Common Forms of Foreign Military Presence
 Several forms of foreign military presence exist within the United States. One common form involves foreign military personnel stationed on U.S. military bases for training purposes. For example, the Euro-NATO Joint Jet Pilot Training Program (ENJJPT) at Sheppard Air Force Base in Texas trains pilots from 14 NATO member nations. Singaporean airmen train at Idaho’s Mountain Home Air Force Base, and British forces train in California. These arrangements allow allied forces to train alongside U.S. counterparts, enhancing interoperability.
 Another form of presence includes foreign liaison offices and military purchasing offices. The German Armed Forces Command in Reston, Virginia, serves as an administrative and logistical hub for German military activities in the U.S. and Canada, coordinating pilot training and managing defense materiel. Foreign Liaison Officers (FLOs) from allied nations are assigned to U.S. Army commands to facilitate cooperation and information exchange. Foreign Military Sales (FMS) offices also facilitate the procurement of U.S. defense articles and services by foreign governments, operating under the Arms Export Control Act. These offices and personnel operate within U.S. facilities and under U.S. regulations.
   
## Legal Basis for Foreign Military Presence
 Foreign military presence in the United States is established by invitation and governed by specific legal agreements. These arrangements are formalized through memoranda of understanding, executive agreements, or treaties, ensuring all activities remain under U.S. law. Such agreements outline the scope of activities, the number of personnel, and the legal status of foreign military members while on U.S. soil.
 These arrangements are frequently reciprocal, reflecting broader defense cooperation and alliances. While U.S. forces are stationed abroad under Status of Forces Agreements, foreign military personnel in the U.S. are subject to U.S. legal frameworks, including customs regulations and specific exemptions for their baggage and effects. This presence strengthens alliances and improves collective defense capabilities.
